J.D. Vance walked into Donald J. Trump’s office at Mar-a-Lago on a warm winter afternoon in Feb- ruary 2021. The former president had a thick stack of papers on his desk: printouts of Mr. Vance’s co- pious broadsides against Mr. Trump. Mr. Vance’s past criti- cisms had included an essay in one of Mr. Trump’s least favorite magazines, The Atlantic, where Mr. Vance described Mr. Trump as “cultural heroin” — a purveyor of false promises to the white work- ing class. 
Mr. Trump closed the conversa- tion by asking Mr. Vance what he wanted. Mr. Trump told him that everyone else had already been down to Mar-a-Lago begging for his endorsement — a reference to Mr. Vance’s potential opponents in the Ohio Senate primary. 
Mr. Trump, using an expletive, bluntly told Mr. Vance: You said some nasty stuff about me. The discussion that followed was de- scribed in detail by two people with knowledge of the meeting who insisted on anonymity to talk about a private conversation. Mr. Vance’s next move was cru- cial. This was the first time he was meeting Mr. Trump, and Mr. Vance needed the former presi- dent to like him or at least leave the meeting with an open mind.
